name: Robertson–Seymour theorem
rephrased: If a family of graphs is closed under taking minors, then it can be described by forbidding a finite number of specific graphs.
implication_form: If a family of graphs is closed under taking minors, then there exists a finite set of graphs such that the family consists exactly of graphs that do not contain any of these forbidden graphs as minors.
explained: The Robertson–Seymour theorem (also known as the graph minors theorem) states that the set of all undirected graphs, ordered by the relation of graph minors, forms a well-quasi-ordering. This means that there are no infinite strictly decreasing sequences of graphs (antichains) and that any property of graphs that is closed under taking minors can be characterized by forbidding a finite set of specific graphs (forbidden minors). In other words, every minor-closed family of graphs can be defined by a finite list of forbidden minors.
related_conjectures: Kruskal's tree theorem (a foundational result in well-quasi-ordering theory for trees)
Four Color Theorem (historically motivated the search for forbidden minors for planar graphs)
